info.title: Migration Analytics Guide
info.subtitle: Analyzing your VMware environment for migration to Red Hat

abstract.para: This guide provides instructions for installing and using Migration Analytics.

If you have a suggestion for improving this guide or have found an error, please submit a Bugzilla report at http://bugzilla.redhat.com for the Migration Analytics component. Please provide specific details, such as the section number and version, so we can easily locate the content.

preface.title: Preface
preface.simpara: Migration Analytics examines your VMware virtual machines and collects data about their operating systems and workloads, using the Red Hat CloudForms user interface. In CloudForms, you run an analysis scan on the VMware virtual machines and download the collected data as an inventory data file.

You create a report with the Migration Analytics service, which uploads the inventory data file and analyzes it. The report provides an estimate of the initial savings in migrating to Red Hat, a detailed analysis of the VMware virtual machines, and recommendations to help you plan your migration.
Migration Analytics supports VMware version 6.0 or later.

note.simpara: Migration Analytics is available as a technology preview for Red Hat CloudForms 5.0. For more information on the support scope for features marked as technology previews, see Technology Preview Features Support Scope.

chapter.title: Understanding Migration Analytics
chapter.simpara: You can scan your VMware virtual machines in CloudForms and create a report with the Migration Analytics service.

section.title: Migration Analytics workflow
section.simpara: The following workflow describes how Migration Analytics works.
20 In the CloudForms user interface, you perform a SmartState analysis scan on your VMware virtual machines.
20 Data about operating systems and workloads is collected from the VMware virtual machines.
The following workloads are currently supported:

listitem.simpara: JBoss Core Service Apache HTTP server with mod_cluster configured
JBoss EAP
PostgreSQL
SAP HANA
Apache Tomcat
Oracle Weblogic
IBM WebSphere
Microsoft SQL

section.simpara: 20 The data from the VMware virtual machines is collected in an inventory data file, which you can download to your local machine to view.
20 In a browser, you navigate to the Migration Analytics service and create a report. The Migration Analytics service uploads the inventory data file and analyzes it.
20 The Migration Analytics service generates a report describing the estimated savings, the complexity of the migration, and migration recommendations.

section.title: Migration Analytics report
section.simpara: The Migration Analytics report is generated by the Migration Analytics service at https://cloud.redhat.com/beta and is displayed in your browser. You can filter the results or download the report.
The report contains the following sections.

formalpara.title: Initial savings estimation
formalpara.para: This section describes the estimated savings realized by migrating from VMware to Red Hat Virtualization over a three-year period, based on the data retrieved from the infrastructure. The savings estimates are broken down into VMware maintenance costs, Red Hat Virtualization costs, and Red Hat training and services.

formalpara.title: Workload migration summary
formalpara.para: This section describes the complexity of the migration and provides detailed workload data. A pie chart displays the complexity of migrations:

listitem.simpara: Easy: Virtual machine with no unusual configuration
Medium: For example, virtual machine with more than four vNICs or a shared disk
Hard: For example, a virtual machine with Raw Device Mapping
Unsupported: Operating system is not supported for migration, for example, FreeBSD 12

formalpara.title: Workload migration inventory
formalpara.para: This section displays a list of the virtual machines to be migrated, with detailed information about each virtual machineâ€™s workload, operating system, estimated migration effort, and recommended migration targets.

section.simpara: In this section, you can filter the list of virtual machines by fields or click Export as CSV to save the report to your local machine.

chapter.title: Deploying Migration Analytics
chapter.simpara: You can deploy Migration Analytics by installing CloudForms on VMware, adding the VMware provider, and configuring CloudForms.

section.title: Installing CloudForms
section.simpara: You can install Red Hat CloudForms on VMware vSphere.

listitem.simpara: VMware vSphere 6.0 or later
VMware support credentials, for downloading VDDK
CloudForms 5.0
Download and install CloudForms on VMware vSphere.
Configure the CloudForms database.
Download and install VDDK.
VDDK is required for running a SmartState analysis scan on VMware virtual machines.

section.title: Adding a provider to CloudForms
section.simpara: You can add VMware as an infrastructure provider to CloudForms.

listitem.simpara: Log in to the Cloudforms user interface and change the default password.
Add VMware vCenter as an infrastructure provider to CloudForms.
Add the VMware host credentials to CloudForms.

section.title: Assigning a control policy
section.simpara: You can assign a control policy to the vSphere provider.

listitem.simpara: Log in to the CloudForms user interface.
Navigate to Compute â†’ Infrastructure â†’ Providers and select the vSphere provider.
Click Policy â†’ Manage Policies.
Select the VM SmartState Analysis profile control policy to add it to the vSphere provider.
A gold shield on the provider icon indicates that the control policy was successfully added.

section.title: Configuring Red Hat CloudForms for Migration Analytics
section.simpara: You can configure Red Hat CloudForms for Migration Analytics.

listitem.simpara: Log in to the CloudForms user interface.

In the header bar, click
config gear (Configuration).
Click the Settings accordion and then click Zones.
Click the zone in which the EVM server is located and select your EVM server.
In the Server tab, scroll down to Server Roles.
Set SmartProxy to On.

note.simpara: SmartState analysis is On by default. Do not change this setting.

listitem.simpara: In the Advanced tab, under :prototype::migration_analytics:, change the value of the enabled parameter to true:
Click Save.
Log out of the CloudForms user interface.
Log in to the CloudForms machine as root.
Restart the EVM server:

chapter.title: Managing analysis profiles
chapter.simpara: A default analysis profile is used for scanning your VMware virtual machines.
You can create a custom analysis profile by modifying the custom_profile.yaml template in .
You can export existing analysis profiles for backup, troubleshooting, or updates.

section.title: Creating a default analysis profile
section.simpara: You can create a default analysis profile for Migration Analytics by copying the Sample analysis profile provided in CloudForms.

note.simpara: If you create an analysis profile with a name other than default, you must create a control policy and assign it to the vSphere provider.
If a default analysis profile does not exist or if you have not created a control policy to assign a different analysis profile, no profile is used for the scan.

listitem.simpara: Log in to the CloudForms user interface.

In the header bar, click
config gear (Configuration).
Click the Settings accordion and then click Analysis Profiles.
Select the Sample analysis profile.
Click Configuration â†’ Copy this selected Analysis Profile.
Enter default in the Name field and click Add.
The default profile appears under Analysis Profiles.

section.title: Creating a customized analysis profile
section.simpara: You can create a customized analysis profile so that custom workloads and instances are detected, added to the inventory data file, and included in the Migration Analytics report.

listitem.simpara: If there is an existing default analysis profile in CloudForms, you must delete it.
Importing a new default profile does not overwrite an existing default profile. The import process concatenates the default profiles.
Log in to the CloudForms machine as root.
Create a /root/custom_profile.yaml file, using the custom_profile.yaml file as a template.
Edit the custom_profile.yaml file for your workloads by updating the target parameters.
For example, you can modify the paths to startup scripts and configuration files for custom Oracle WebLogic instances:
listitem.programlisting: --- name: default definition: - name: default_file guid: item_type: file definition: stats: - target: /u01/app/oracle/domains/base/bin/startNodeManager.sh - target: /u01/app/oracle/domains/base/startWebLogic.sh - target: /home/oracle/oraInventory - target: /u01/app/oracle/domains/base/config/config.xml

callout.para: The imported analysis profile is called default. If you change the profile name, you must create a control policy and add it to the vSphere provider.

listitem.simpara: Save the custom_profile.yaml file.
Go to the vmdb directory:
Import the custom_profile.yaml file:
In the CloudForms user interface, verify that the default profile appears under Analysis Profiles.

section.title: Exporting analysis profiles
section.simpara: You can export your analysis profiles for backup, troubleshooting, or updating.

listitem.simpara: Log in to the CloudForms machine as root.
Go to the vmdb directory:
Create an export directory:
Export the analysis profiles:

callout.para: The --all option exports all the analysis profiles as yaml files. There is no option to export a single analysis profile.

chapter.title: Collecting data for Migration Analytics
chapter.simpara: You can scan your VMware virtual machines and download the results as an inventory data file to your local machine.
Optionally, you can combine multiple inventory data files into a single file in order to generate a single Migration Analytics report.

section.title: Scanning the virtual machines
section.simpara: You can scan your VMware virtual machines in Red Hat CloudForms.

important.simpara: Some virtual machines should not be analyzed because the snapshot process may cause data corruption. See the VMware documentation about snapshot limitations for details.
You can exclude a virtual machine from the scan by assigning to it the exclusions tag, with the do_not_analyze value.

listitem.simpara: SmartState analysis and SmartProxy must be enabled.
You must have a valid VM analysis profile called default. If you create an analysis profile with a different name, you must create a control policy and assign it to the vSphere provider.
Log in to the CloudForms user interface.
Navigate to Compute â†’ Infrastructure â†’ Virtual Machines.
Select the virtual machines that you want to scan.
Click Configuration â†’ Perform SmartState Analysis.
Each virtual machine can take up to one minute to scan.

Click your username
user â†’ Tasks.
The result of each SmartState analysis scan appears in My Tasks.

section.title: Creating and downloading inventory files
section.simpara: You can create and download inventory data files for your vSphere provider.

listitem.simpara: The Migration Analytics menu must be enabled in the CloudForms user interface.
You must first perform an analysis scan on the VMware virtual machines.
Log in to the CloudForms user interface.
Navigate to Compute â†’ Infrastructure â†’ Providers and select the VMware provider.
Click Configuration â†’ Refresh Relationships and Power States and click OK.
Navigate to Migration â†’ Migration Analytics and click Get started.
A summary page listing all providers is displayed.
Click vSphere to view the provider summary.
Click Collect Inventory Data.
Select vSphere from the provider list.
Select Detailed Data and click Continue.
Click Download Inventory File and save the inventory file.

section.title: Combining multiple inventory files
section.simpara: You can combine multiple inventory files, for example, from different data centers, into a single file in order to generate a single Migration Analytics report.

listitem.simpara: You must ensure that the inventory files do not contain duplicate information.
Log in to the CloudForms machine.
Create a common directory for the extracted inventory files:
Extract an inventory file to the common directory:
Rename the extracted JSON inventory file. Each file name must be unique.
Create a new archive file containing the extracted inventory files:

callout.para: Specify the new archive file name.

section.simpara: You can browse to the new archive file when you create a Migration Analytics report.

chapter.title: Creating and filtering a Migration Analytics report
chapter.simpara: You can create a Migration Analytics report, filter the results, and export the data.

section.title: Creating a Migration Analytics report
section.simpara: You can create a report with the Migration Analytics service.

listitem.simpara: Inventory data file generated by Red Hat CloudForms or a tar.gz archive containing multiple inventory data files
Access to https://cloud.redhat.com/beta
Launch a browser and navigate to https://cloud.redhat.com/beta.
In the Migration Services tile, click Open.
The Reports window is displayed.
Click Create and fill in the following fields:
Mandatory fields:
Inventory data file: Inventory data file generated by CloudForms. Click Browse to select the tar.gz file.
Report name: Name of your report, up to 250 characters
Year-over-year growth rate for new hypervisors: Number of new hypervisors to be added each year
Optional fields:
Report description: Brief description of your report
Percentage of new hypervisors migrated each year: Percentage of new hypervisors that you intend to migrate each year.
Click Create report.
The inventory data file is uploaded and the generated report appears in the Reports list.

section.title: Filtering a Migration Analytics report
section.simpara: You can filter the results of a Migration Analytics report to display virtual machines according to provider, cluster, migration effort, and other parameters.

listitem.simpara: Migration Analytics report
Launch a browser and navigate to https://cloud.redhat.com/beta.
In the Migration Services tile, click Open.
Click a Migration Analytics report name to view the report.
Click Workload Migration Inventory to view a detailed list of the virtual machines.
Click Filter and select a filter type.
Click Filter by <filter_type> and select one or more options.
The filtered virtual machines are displayed.
Click Filter > Workload.
Click Filter by Workload and select one or more workloads, for example, Tomcat, Oracle Database, or Microsoft SQL Server.

example.title: Filtering candidates for migration to RHEL

listitem.simpara: Click Filter > Recommended targets.
Click Filter by Recommended targets > RHEL.
Click Filter > Flags IMS.
Click Filter by Flags IMS and select one or more flags, for example, RDM (Raw Device Mapping) or Shared Disk.

section.title: Exporting a Migration Analytics report
section.simpara: You can export a Migration Analytics report in CSV format.

listitem.simpara: Migration Analytics report
Launch a browser and navigate to https://cloud.redhat.com/beta.
In the Migration Services tile, click Open.
Click a Migration Analytics report name to view the report.
Click Workload Migration Inventory to view a detailed list of the virtual machines.
Click Export as CSV.
The entire Migration Analytics report is downloaded to your local machine as a CSV file.

chapter.title: Troubleshooting
chapter.simpara: You can troubleshoot errors in the Migration Analytics data collection and report generation processes.

listitem.simpara: Updating a manifest
A manifest file is provided with the Red Hat CloudForms appliance to create a payload for Migration Analytics. You can update your manifest with an upstream version.

appendix.title: custom_profile.yaml template
appendix.simpara: You can modify the custom_profile.yaml template to create a customized analysis profile for scanning your workloads.

callout.para: If you change the profile name from default, you must create a control policy and add it to the vSphere provider.
You can add or modify targets for item_type: file.
Do not change content: true for this target.
